Clinton Visits Nigeria To Encourage Democracy President Clinton began a four-day trip to Africa, landing in Nigeria to help support the shaky transition of Africa's most populous country to civilian rule from 16 years of entrenched military dictatorship.

Clinton Visits Nigeria To Encourage Democracy President Clinton began a four-day trip to Africa, landing in Nigeria to help support the shaky transition of Africa's most populous country to civilian rule from 16 years of entrenched military dictatorship.

Wild Card in the Middle East Sheikh Ahmed Yassin and Hamas, the Islamic militant group which he serves as spiritual leader, remain the wild card of Middle East politics, their unreconciled hatred for Israel a lurking threat to destabilize peace.
New Focus on Mubarak The Clinton administration is focusing on the Egyptian leader, Hosni Mubarak, as the key to finding a solution in the Middle East, particularly on the future status of Jerusalem.

Troubled Election in Lebanon Lebanese begin voting today in a parliamentary election marked by a deepening economic crisis, widespread public cynicism and startlingly open denunciations of vote rigging and Syrian domination.
British Troops Captured One of the rival factions fighting in Sierra Leone kidnapped 11 British soldiers who are part of a force trying to bring order to the country.

Sanctions Hurting Afghanistan A report by the United Nations' relief coordinator in Afghanistan says that the existing economic embargo is having ''a tangible negative effect'' on the country and on efforts to help the Afghan people.

Algerian Cabinet Resigns Citing differences within his cabinet and with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Prime Minister Ahmed Benbitour handed in the resignation of his government and was replaced by Mr. Bouteflika's chief of staff, Ali Benflis. (Agence France-Presse)
NATIONAL

As a Senator, Lieberman Is Proudly Pro-Business Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has closely aligned himself with three industries -- insurance, high technology and health care -- that are the main sources of his campaign contributions. His pro-business record contrasts sharply with the larger message that Vice President Al Gore has been sending recently.

Gov. George W. Bush has embraced his state's growing Mexican-American population. Yet Hispanics in Texas remain more likely to be poor, unemployed and without health insurance, problems that predate Mr. Bush but that his critics say he has done too little to address.

Prayer at Games Students throughout the South are praying in the stands before football games, but school officials have carefully stayed out of the way in order not to violate a June decision of the United States Supreme Court.
Pilots Reach Tentative Deal United Airlines and its pilots reached a tentative agreement in a contract dispute that forced the world's largest airline to cancel more than 20,000 flights.
New Prison Questioned A plan for a new $335 million prison has galvanized groups across California, who want the state to rethink its policies limiting paroles.

Deutch Investigation A special prosecutor investigating John M. Deutch, the former director of the C.I.A., expects to recommend that he be prosecuted for mishandling classified information, government officials said.
Nixon and Self-Medication A new biography says that President Richard M. Nixon medicated himself with a mood-altering prescription drug in the White House.
NEW YORK/REGION

Electricity Deregulation May Have a Hidden Cost The recently deregulated energy market, which was supposed to reduce prices in New York State has, for many residents, done nothing of the kind. Community leaders and politicians, calling for investigations and caps on rising electricity bills -- up 30 percent to 40 percent from those of last August in many areas -- have denounced energy deregulation as either a failure or a fraud.

Suburbs Reviving Downtowns All over the New York region -- and throughout the country -- suburban communities are struggling to reverse a decline that began decades ago as shoppers fled the central business districts of older suburbs for outlying malls, leaving behind deserted commercial streets.

Killing Rampage in Connecticut Mark Cote, a 29-year-old phlebotomist, went on a killing rampage in Waterbury, Conn., gunning down a neighbor, a city firefighter and the mother of an ex-girlfriend in less than 15 minutes, before killing himself, the police said.

Lynden O. Pindling The former leader of the Bahamas whose reputation and relationship with the United States was marred by unresolved accuations of protecting drug traffickers, he was 70.

Edward Craven Walker A champion of nudism and designer of the Lava lamp, he was 82. The Singapore-born entrepreneur took an unusual egg timer he found at a pub and turned it into a must-have item for a generation of dormitory students.
